content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Lorenzo Johnson: I was born in Newark, New Jersey, and I've spent most of my life here, which has shaped who I am in a lot of ways. My parents were divorced when I was young, so I grew up in a single-parent household with my mom. She worked hard to make sure I had everything I needed, and she was always pushing me to do well in school. My dad was around sometimes, but he wasn't really involved in my life after the divorce. My mom has a bachelor's degree, and she worked full-time, so I saw the value of education early on. I was a pretty quiet kid, always reading books or getting lost in my thoughts. I didn't have a lot of money growing up, but we were never in a bad situation—just average. I remember feeling like I had to work twice as hard to prove myself, especially in school, because I was one of the few Black kids in my advanced classes. I ended up going to college on a scholarship, and later I got my graduate degree. Now, I'm back in school again, trying to finish my master's in social work. I want to help people in my community, especially kids who come from backgrounds similar to mine. It's a long road, but I believe in the power of education and the importance of giving back.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Lorenzo Johnson: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads. I was in my junior year of high school, and I had the chance to apply for a summer internship at a local nonprofit that worked with at-risk youth. I was really torn because I also had the option to take a job at a convenience store to help my mom out with bills. I remember sitting on the floor of my bedroom, staring at the application, trying to figure out what was more important—making money now or investing in my future. In the end, I went with the internship. It was tough because I had to work late nights and weekends, but it changed everything for me. I saw how much impact someone could have by being there for kids who didn't have much. That experience made me realize I wanted to be a social worker. It was the moment I decided my path wasn't just about getting a good job—it was about making a difference in people's lives, especially in my community. I've never looked back since.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Lorenzo Johnson: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way you might expect. I wasn't just thinking about my future—I was thinking about the people around me, especially the kids in my neighborhood who didn't have the same opportunities I did. I remember talking to my mom about it one night, and she said something that stuck with me: 'You have a chance to do something bigger than just yourself, Lorenzo. Don't waste it.' That moment made me realize I wasn't just making a decision for myself; I was making a decision for others. I didn't see it as a crossroads in the traditional sense, but more like a responsibility that I couldn't ignore. I chose the internship because I knew it was the right thing to do, even if it wasn't the easiest path.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Lorenzo Johnson: Absolutely. I think if there had been more programs in our neighborhood that supported kids like me—programs that gave us opportunities to explore different careers or connect with mentors—it could have made a huge difference. I remember there was a community center near my old school that used to offer after-school activities, but it closed down a few years before I got to high school. If that place had still been around, I might have had more exposure to what social work even was. I also think organizations that provide scholarships or internships to students from low-income backgrounds are essential. I was lucky to get that internship, but not everyone has that same chance. I wish I had had someone who could have guided me through that decision, someone who could have helped me see the bigger picture before I had to figure it out on my own.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Lorenzo Johnson: Right now, I don't have a partner or any children, but my mom is definitely the most important person in my life. She's been my rock through everything, and I don't take her sacrifices for granted. I also have a younger sister who's in college, and we talk often. She's following a similar path to mine—trying to balance school, work, and family responsibilities. I admire her strength, and I try to be there for her as much as I can. I don't see myself getting married anytime soon, but if I do, I want to make sure I'm with someone who shares my values and who I can grow with. For now, my focus is on my studies and making sure I'm in a position to help others the way my mom helped me. Family has always been central to who I am, and I hope to build a life that honors that.

Going through those interview questions felt like looking back at the different chapters of my life and seeing how each one shaped me. Starting with the story of my life, I realized how much my childhood and upbringing influenced my values and goals. Talking about the crossroads I faced in high school reminded me of the weight of decisions and how one choice can set you on a new path. When I reflected on whether it was a conscious choice or something that just happened, I saw how deeply my sense of responsibility to others played a role. I also thought about how much support I wish I had received from others during those times, and how important it is to give that same support to others now. Finally, thinking about my family reminded me of where I came from and who I want to be moving forward. These questions didn't just ask about my past—they helped me see how my past is still shaping my future.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Lorenzo Johnson: My dad is still around, though we don't talk as much as I'd like. He was in the military for a few years, and after he came back, things got complicated. He wasn't really there for me after the divorce, and I think he struggled with his own demons. I don't hold it against him, but I also don't have a close relationship with him. We see each other at family gatherings, and it's always a bit awkward, like we're trying to be polite but not really connecting. I know he had his own challenges, and I hope he's doing okay. I just don't know if I'll ever have that kind of bond with him the way I have with my mom. She's the one who raised me, who believed in me when I didn't believe in myself, and I'll always be grateful for that.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Lorenzo Johnson: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been really important to me. One of them is Marcus, who I met in high school through that same nonprofit internship. We bonded over our shared experiences growing up in Newark and our desire to make a difference. He ended up becoming a teacher, and he's been a huge support system for me throughout my education. Then there's Aisha, who's a social worker too, and she's been like a mentor to me. She's the one who encouraged me to apply for my master's program. I also have a few close friends from college who I stay in touch with, even though we're all in different stages of our lives. They've been there for me through the ups and downs, and I know I can always count on them. I think having people who believe in you and push you to be better is really important, especially when you're trying to navigate life on your own.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Lorenzo Johnson: I live in a neighborhood in Newark that's a mix of old and new—some parts still have that classic urban feel with brick buildings and tight-knit communities, while other areas are seeing new developments and investments. It's a place that's constantly changing, and I think that's both a challenge and an opportunity. I live in a small apartment near campus, but I still make it a point to spend time in the neighborhoods where I grew up. There's something about walking through the streets of my childhood, seeing the same corner stores and churches, that reminds me of where I came from. I also try to stay involved in local initiatives that aim to improve education and youth programs, because I know how much of a difference that can make. It's not perfect, and there are definitely struggles here—poverty, crime, systemic issues—but there's also a lot of resilience. People here are fighters, and I want to be part of that fight, even if it's just in small ways. My neighborhood isn't just where I live; it's where I want to leave a mark.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Lorenzo Johnson: Honestly, it's a mix. There are parts of Newark where I feel safe, especially the areas where I grew up and where I still have a lot of familiar faces. People know each other, and there's a sense of community that keeps things grounded. But there are also parts of the city where I'm more cautious, especially late at night or in areas that have seen a lot of change without the same level of investment. I've had moments where I've felt uneasy walking alone, especially if I'm in a part of town I don't know well. But I try not to let that fear define my experience. I've always believed that safety starts with awareness and community support. I know there are people working hard to make Newark a better place, and I want to be part of that effort. Safety isn't just about avoiding danger—it's about building something stronger, something that protects everyone, especially the kids who are still finding their way.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Lorenzo Johnson: Living here has been a mix of challenges and rewards. On one hand, I love the sense of community and the history that's embedded in the streets. There's a rhythm to life here that you can't find anywhere else—like the sound of church bells in the morning or the way people greet each other on the corner. But it's also a place that tests you. I've seen friends struggle with jobs, housing, and just trying to make ends meet. It's not easy being young, Black, and trying to build a future in a city that still has a lot of work to do. But I also see the resilience every day. People here don't back down. They find ways to survive, to thrive, even when the odds are stacked against them. I've learned to appreciate the struggle because it's part of what makes me who I am. I want to be a part of something bigger than myself, and I think Newark is where that starts for me.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how deeply connected I am to the people and places that shaped me. Talking about my mom and sister reminded me of the strength and sacrifices that have always been at the heart of my journey. It also made me think about how important it is to support others in the same way they supported me. When I described my neighborhood, I realized how much it still means to me—not just as a place to live, but as a part of my identity. I see the challenges, but I also see the resilience, and I want to be part of that resilience. I want to help build something better, not just for myself, but for the kids who come after me. These questions didn't just ask about my past—they made me think about how I can shape my future, and how I can give back to the community that gave me so much.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Lorenzo Johnson: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it varies depending on my classes and any community work I'm involved in. I usually start my week on Monday with classes at the university, which are pretty intense since I'm juggling a full course load with part-time work at a local community center. I work there a few afternoons a week, helping with youth programs and tutoring. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are mostly about studying and attending workshops related to social work. I try to set aside time each day to read or reflect, especially on the experiences I had growing up and how they shape my approach to helping others. Thursdays are often the busiest day because I have a group meeting with other students in my program, and we discuss case studies and community projects. Fridays are a bit more relaxed, but I still try to stay productive. I might go to a local event or meet up with friends to decompress. Weekends are usually for family time—visiting my mom, catching up with my sister, or just taking a walk through the neighborhood. I find that keeping a balance between my studies, work, and personal life is essential, especially when I'm trying to stay focused on my goals. It's not always easy, but I remind myself that every step I take is part of a bigger journey—one that I hope will lead me to making a real difference in people's lives.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Lorenzo Johnson: Right now, I work part-time at a local community center in the afternoons, usually Tuesday through Friday, helping with youth programs and tutoring. It's not a high-paying job, but it's meaningful because I get to work directly with kids from my neighborhood—some of them are in the same situation I was in when I was their age. I also do some volunteer work on weekends with a nonprofit that focuses on education and mentorship for at-risk youth. It's a lot to juggle, but I feel like it's all part of the journey. I'm also working toward my master's in social work, so I take on extra responsibilities whenever I can. I know it's not the easiest path, but I believe in what I'm doing. I want to be someone who can show these kids that there's a way out, that they don't have to stay stuck in the same cycle I almost did. It's hard work, but I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Lorenzo Johnson: Outside of work and school, I try to stay grounded by keeping up with my fitness routine. I go to the gym a few times a week, usually in the mornings before classes start. It helps me clear my mind and stay focused. I also make it a point to read every night—whether it's fiction, nonfiction, or something related to social work. Reading has always been a way for me to escape, but it's also how I learn and grow. I try to stay connected with my roots by attending church services on Sundays, which is something I've done since I was a kid. It's not just about faith for me; it's about community, about being part of something bigger. I also take time to mentor a few high school students through a local program, which is something I'm really passionate about. It's amazing how much you can learn from kids when you're willing to listen, and it reminds me why I chose this path in the first place.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Lorenzo Johnson: One of the biggest changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more structured time for self-reflection and journaling. I started doing this a few months ago after realizing how much I was carrying in my head without really processing it. I set aside about 20 minutes each morning before my gym session to write down my thoughts, goals, and even the small victories from the day before. It's helped me stay more centered, especially with everything going on with school, work, and the community projects I'm involved in. I also started attending a few more local meetings with other social workers and activists in the area, which has expanded my network and given me new ideas for how to approach some of the challenges we face. It's been a slow but meaningful shift, and I think it's helping me grow both personally and professionally.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Lorenzo Johnson: I don't have children yet, but if I did, I would want their daily routine to reflect the values I hold dear—education, community, and personal growth. A typical weekday for them would start with a healthy breakfast, followed by school, and then some time for homework or reading. I would make sure they had access to after-school activities that challenge them and help them discover their interests, whether it's sports, music, or community service. I'd also want them to have time to just be kids, to play and explore. If they were involved in any programs, I'd want them to be ones that encourage leadership and empathy, just like the ones that helped shape me. I know how important it is to have role models and opportunities, so I'd do everything I could to make sure they had that support system in place.

Going through the interview topics from questions 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply connected I am to the people and places that shaped me. Talking about my family reminded me of the strength and sacrifices that have always been at the heart of my journey, and it made me realize how important it is to support others in the same way they supported me. When I described my neighborhood, I saw how much it still means to me—not just as a place to live, but as a part of my identity. I see the challenges, but I also see the resilience, and I want to be part of that resilience. I want to help build something better, not just for myself, but for the kids who come after me. Reflecting on my daily routines and responsibilities also made me appreciate how much I've grown and how much I still have to give. It's not just about where I've been—it's about where I'm going and how I can help others get there too.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Lorenzo Johnson: As for my health, I'd say I'm in pretty good shape overall, but I wouldn't call it perfect. I've always been pretty active, especially when I was younger, but life has a way of slowing you down a bit. I used to play basketball in high school, and I still enjoy it when I can find the time. I've had my share of stress-related issues, though—especially during my college years when I was juggling school, work, and family responsibilities. I remember a few times when I was so overwhelmed that I started getting headaches and trouble sleeping. That's when I realized I needed to take better care of myself. Now, I make sure to go to the gym regularly, eat as healthy as I can, and try to get enough rest. I also take some medication for anxiety, something I've dealt with off and on throughout my life. It's not something I'm ashamed of, but it's something I've had to learn how to manage. I've been seeing a therapist for a while now, and that's helped a lot. I think mental health is just as important as physical health, and I'm trying to be more proactive about both. I want to be there for the kids I work with, and I know I can't do that if I'm not taking care of myself first.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Lorenzo Johnson: Staying healthy isn't always easy, especially when you're juggling so many responsibilities. There are days when I'm so caught up in work, school, and trying to make a difference that I forget to take a break. It's hard to find the time to eat right or get enough sleep when I'm up late studying or helping kids at the community center. But what makes it easier is knowing that taking care of myself isn't just about me—it's about being there for the people I care about. When I feel overwhelmed, I remind myself that I can't pour from an empty cup. That's why I try to stick to my routine as much as possible, even on the busiest days. I also find that talking to my therapist or just having a good conversation with a friend helps me reset. It's not always perfect, but I'm learning that small, consistent efforts go a long way in keeping both my mind and body in check.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Lorenzo Johnson: In the past two years, I've had a few health challenges that I didn't expect. About a year ago, I started experiencing persistent back pain, which I initially thought was just from sitting too long at the community center or studying. But after a few months of it getting worse, I finally went to the doctor. Turns out, I had a herniated disc in my lower back. It was a bit of a wake-up call. I had to take a short break from work and school to focus on physical therapy and rest. It was tough because I felt like I was falling behind, but I knew I couldn't keep pushing through the pain. I also had to reevaluate how I was managing my time and stress. Around the same time, I started having more frequent anxiety attacks, which made me realize I needed to be even more intentional about my mental health. I've been working closely with my therapist to develop better coping strategies, and I've also started practicing mindfulness and meditation. It's been a journey, but I'm grateful for the reminder that my health is something I can't ignore. I've learned that taking care of myself isn't just about being strong—it's about being smart and knowing when to slow down and heal.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Lorenzo Johnson: Honestly, it's been challenging at times. When I was dealing with the back pain and the anxiety, there were days when I struggled to get through my classes or even show up for work. I had to ask for some flexibility with my schedule, which wasn't easy because I didn't want to let the kids at the community center down. I remember one day, after a particularly bad flare-up, I had to cancel a tutoring session and felt awful about it. But what I learned was that asking for help isn't a weakness—it's a sign of strength. I had to be honest with my supervisor, my professors, and even my therapist about how I was feeling. It forced me to slow down and really listen to my body and mind. I also had to adjust my routines, like taking more breaks during the day and prioritizing rest. It wasn't perfect, but it taught me that I can't do everything on my own. I need support, and I need to be willing to accept it when it's offered. I think that's something I want to model for the kids I work with too—showing them that it's okay to struggle, but it's also important to take care of yourself so you can keep going.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Lorenzo Johnson: Over the past year, I've been going through a lot of personal growth, but it hasn't always been easy. There were moments when I felt like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders—trying to balance school, work, community responsibilities, and my own health. I've had to learn how to set boundaries, how to say no when I need to, and how to take time for myself without feeling guilty about it. I've also been reflecting a lot on my purpose, especially after dealing with that back injury and the anxiety flare-ups. It made me realize how important it is to take care of myself so I can be there for others. I've started to lean more into my support system—my mom, my friends, my therapist—and that's been a huge relief. I've also found more peace in my faith, which has helped me stay grounded during tough times. It's been a year of challenges, but it's also been a year of learning, healing, and rediscovering what really matters to me.

Going through the interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much I've grown in understanding the importance of my own well-being. Talking about my daily routines and the changes I've made, like journaling and attending more community meetings, reminded me that growth isn't just about external achievements—it's also about how I take care of myself. When I discussed my health, I realized how much I've been carrying without really addressing it, and how important it is to be honest about my struggles. I used to think that being strong meant pushing through everything on my own, but now I see that true strength comes from knowing when to slow down, ask for help, and prioritize my mental and physical health. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that taking care of myself is the only way I can truly help others. These reflections have helped me see that my journey isn't just about making a difference in my community—it's also about making sure I'm in a place where I can keep going, day after day.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Lorenzo Johnson: I think I've struggled with anxiety more than anything else, though I didn't always recognize it for what it was. There were times in college when I felt like I was constantly on edge, like I was waiting for something bad to happen, even when I had nothing to worry about. I used to push through it, thinking that if I just worked harder, I could outpace the feelings. But over time, I realized that ignoring it wasn't helping me or anyone else. I started seeing a therapist a few years back, and that was one of the best decisions I've made. It's not that I'm completely free of it now, but I understand it better, and I have tools to manage it. I also try to be open about it with the kids I work with, because I want them to know that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, and that asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. I've come a long way, but I know it's a journey—one that I'm still learning how to navigate.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Lorenzo Johnson: For my family, it's been a mix of support and concern. My mom has always been there for me, but I think she's worried about the stress I'm under with school, work, and everything else. She doesn't say it out loud, but I can tell she's watching me closely, making sure I'm taking care of myself. She's been my biggest supporter, and I know she's proud of me, even when I'm not sure I'm proud of myself. My sister, on the other hand, has been more of a sounding board. She's been through a lot of the same things I have, so she understands what I'm going through. We talk a lot about our struggles, our hopes, and sometimes just about the little things—like how we both miss our dad, even if we don't always get along with him. It's been hard for them to see me go through this, but I think they're also seeing how much I'm growing. I know I'm not the same person I was when I was younger, and I think that's something they're proud of, even if they don't always say it.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Lorenzo Johnson: For me, religion has always been a grounding force, especially growing up in Newark. My mom was very involved in our church, and I remember sitting in those pews as a kid, listening to sermons that spoke about resilience, justice, and the importance of community. It wasn't just about faith for me—it was about belonging, about knowing that no matter what was going on in my life, there was a place where I could feel supported. Even now, attending church on Sundays is something I still do. It's not just about the rituals or the hymns; it's about the people, the sense of purpose, and the reminder that I'm part of something bigger than myself. I think that's why I'm so passionate about helping others—it's like living out the teachings I heard growing up. I may not always have all the answers, but I know that faith has been a part of my journey, and I want to carry that with me as I continue to grow and serve my community.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Lorenzo Johnson: I use social media mostly to stay connected with my community and to share stories that I think need to be heard. I follow a lot of local activists, educators, and organizations that are doing important work in Newark and beyond. I also use Instagram to post about my journey—whether it's about my studies, my work with kids, or just my daily reflections. It's a way for me to stay inspired and to remind others that they're not alone in their struggles. I try to be intentional about what I share, though. I don't post just for the sake of it; I want my content to matter, to spark conversations, or to encourage someone else to keep going. I also use Facebook to stay in touch with family and old friends, especially my mom and sister. It's amazing how much you can stay connected with people even when life gets busy. I've even started following some social workers and mentors in my field, and it's been really helpful to see how they approach their work. Social media isn't perfect, but for me, it's a tool to stay grounded, informed, and connected to the people and causes that matter most.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Lorenzo Johnson: Honestly, I've found that social media can be a double-edged sword when it comes to support. On one hand, there are times when I'll post about something I'm going through—like a tough day at work or a personal struggle—and I'll get messages from people who relate, who share their own stories, or who just say, 'You're not alone.' That kind of emotional support has been really meaningful, especially when I'm feeling isolated or overwhelmed. I remember one time when I posted about my back pain and the anxiety I was dealing with, and a few people from my community reached out to check in on me. It reminded me that even though I'm trying to be strong, it's okay to show vulnerability. On the other hand, I've also seen how social media can amplify stress or comparisons, especially when I'm scrolling through people's highlight reels and feeling like I'm falling behind. So I try to be mindful of how I use it—focusing on the positive, the supportive, and the real, rather than letting it become a source of pressure. For me, it's about balance, and I'm learning that even in tough times, there's power in sharing your story and knowing that someone, somewhere, might be listening.

Going through the interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health has shaped my journey over the past year. Talking about my back injury and anxiety flare-ups reminded me of how much I've been pushing through without really addressing my needs. It's not easy to admit when you're struggling, especially when you're trying to be strong for others, but I've learned that true strength comes from knowing when to slow down and take care of yourself. I used to think that being resilient meant never showing weakness, but now I see that vulnerability is a form of strength too. When I discussed how my health challenges affected my work and responsibilities, it made me realize how important it is to ask for help and accept support when it's offered. I'm still learning how to balance everything—school, work, community, and my own well-being—but I'm starting to understand that taking care of myself isn't a distraction from my goals; it's the foundation that allows me to keep going. These reflections have helped me see that my journey isn't just about making a difference in my community—it's also about making sure I'm in a place where I can keep going, day after day, without burning out.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Lorenzo Johnson: In the past few months, I've noticed my stress levels have actually decreased a bit, which is something I didn't expect. I think it's because I've started to embrace the idea that I don't have to be perfect or have everything figured out all the time. I used to feel like I had to carry every burden on my own, but now I've learned to lean on my support system more—whether it's my mom, my friends, or even the kids I work with. I've also been more consistent with my self-care routines, like journaling, going to the gym, and attending church. It's not that I don't still have days where I feel overwhelmed, but I've developed better coping strategies. When I feel stress creeping in, I take a step back, breathe, and remind myself why I'm doing this. I remind myself of the kids I'm trying to help, the community I want to build, and the person I'm becoming. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that it's okay to feel, and it's okay to grow through those feelings.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Lorenzo Johnson: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. I live in a small apartment near campus, and the rent eats up about a third of my income. Groceries are another big chunk because I try to eat healthy, but with my schedule, I often end up buying meal preps or eating out more than I'd like. Public transportation is my main way of getting around, so bus passes and the occasional Uber ride when I'm late for something add up. I also had to set aside some money for my physical therapy sessions after the back injury, which was a necessary expense but one that put a strain on my budget. I work part-time and get some financial aid, but it's still tight. I've had to be really careful with every dollar, sometimes skipping things like going out with friends or buying new clothes just to make sure I can cover my essentials. It's not easy, but I know I'm not alone in this—so many people in my neighborhood are in the same boat. I try to stay focused on what matters most, and that helps me keep going, even when the money is tight.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Lorenzo Johnson: Last month, my household spent just under $1,800, which is actually a bit higher than usual. Normally, I budget around $1,500 to $1,600 a month, but this past month I had to pay for a few unexpected things—like a new pair of shoes for work, since my old ones were worn out, and a small emergency repair on my apartment's heater. I also had to cover the cost of a few extra therapy sessions after I realized I wasn't managing my anxiety as well as I thought I was. It's always a tightrope walk, trying to balance everything without sacrificing my health or my ability to help others. I've learned to track my spending closely, and I try to prioritize essentials like rent, food, and transportation. I also set aside a small amount each month for savings, even if it's just a few dollars. It's not much, but it gives me a sense of control and a little peace of mind, knowing that I'm not just surviving—I'm planning for the future.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Lorenzo Johnson: We rent our home, actually. I live in a small apartment near the university, which is more affordable than trying to find something closer to the city center. Renting has been the only realistic option for me, especially with my current income and student status. I've considered the idea of buying a home someday, but right now, it feels out of reach. I know a lot of people in my neighborhood are in the same situation—renting because owning just isn't feasible. It's one of those things that feels like it's always just out of reach, but I'm not ready to give up on it yet. I want to be in a place where I can settle down, maybe even one day have a family, but for now, I'm focused on making the most of what I have and building a stable future.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Lorenzo Johnson: Over the past year, my bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and my schedule. In the winter, heating costs went up a bit because the apartment's heater wasn't working as well as it should, and I had to pay for repairs and extra heating bills. I also noticed that my transportation costs went up during the holidays because I had to travel more for family events and meetings with my program. In the summer, I used to spend more on groceries because I was eating out more often, but I've been trying to cut back on that and cook at home more. Then there's the cost of my physical therapy and mental health care, which has been pretty consistent but still adds up. I also had to pay for some new work clothes and a few textbooks for my classes, which I didn't budget for at first. It's been a bit of a rollercoaster, but I've learned to adjust my spending as the year goes on, even if it's not always easy. I try to keep track of everything, but sometimes things come up that I didn't plan for, and that's when I have to make tough choices about what's most important.

Going through the interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my health and emotional well-being have shaped my journey over the past year. Talking about my family's support reminded me of how important it is to have people who care, even when they don't always say it out loud. It also made me realize how much I've been carrying without really addressing my needs. I used to think that being strong meant pushing through everything on my own, but now I see that vulnerability is a form of strength too. When I discussed how my health challenges affected my work and responsibilities, it made me realize how important it is to ask for help and accept support when it's offered. I'm still learning how to balance everything—school, work, community, and my own well-being—but I'm starting to understand that taking care of myself isn't a distraction from my goals; it's the foundation that allows me to keep going. These reflections have helped me see that my journey isn't just about making a difference in my community—it's also about making sure I'm in a place where I can keep going, day after day, without burning out.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Lorenzo Johnson: I try to save in small, consistent ways, even if it's just a few dollars each month. I set aside whatever I can after paying my rent, groceries, and transportation costs. It's not a lot, but it gives me a sense of security, knowing that I'm building something for the future—even if it's just a little. I also use a budgeting app to track my spending and remind me when it's time to put something aside. I know it's not the same as having a big savings account, but for someone in my situation, it's about being intentional with every dollar. I also try to save in other ways, like investing in my education or skills, because I believe that's the best way to secure my future. I've seen too many people in my neighborhood struggle without any safety net, and I want to make sure I'm not one of them. Saving isn't always easy, but it's something I take seriously because I know it's the foundation of everything I'm trying to build.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Lorenzo Johnson: For me, saving in the last year has been more about building a rainy day fund than anything else. I know how unpredictable life can be, especially with my health and the demands of school and work. I try to set aside whatever I can each month, even if it's just $20 or $30, because I've seen too many people in my community fall through the cracks when something unexpected happens. I also save in other ways, like investing in my education or skills, because I believe that's the best way to secure my future. I've seen too many people in my neighborhood struggle without any safety net, and I want to make sure I'm not one of them. Saving isn't always easy, but it's something I take seriously because I know it's the foundation of everything I'm trying to build.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Lorenzo Johnson: My current occupation is a part-time social work intern at a local community center, and I'm also working toward my master's degree in social work. The most important activities in my role involve supporting at-risk youth through mentorship, tutoring, and organizing after-school programs that focus on education, personal development, and community engagement. I spend a lot of time listening to the kids I work with, understanding their challenges, and helping them set goals for their future. It's not always easy—there are days when I feel like I'm not making enough of a difference, but then I see a kid who's made progress, or who's found the confidence to keep going, and it reminds me why I'm here. I also work closely with other social workers and community leaders to develop programs that address the root causes of issues like poverty, lack of access to education, and mental health struggles. It's a lot to take on, but I believe in the power of community and the importance of giving people the tools they need to thrive. This work is more than just a job for me—it's a calling, and I'm committed to seeing it through, no matter how long it takes.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Lorenzo Johnson: I usually work around 20 to 25 hours a week, depending on the semester and how many community projects I'm involved in. During the school year, I work Tuesday through Friday afternoons at the community center, which is about 15 to 20 hours. Then there are the weekends, when I volunteer with the nonprofit or meet with students I'm mentoring. It's not a lot, but it's enough to keep me busy and focused. I try to balance it with my studies and self-care, but there are definitely weeks when I feel like I'm running on fumes. Still, I know that every hour I spend working with kids, every conversation I have, and every program I help organize is part of something bigger. It's not just about the hours—it's about the impact, and I'm willing to put in the time to make sure I'm doing it right.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Lorenzo Johnson: I actually haven't had more than one job at a time, but I've taken on different roles depending on what I needed to prioritize. For example, during the summer months when I wasn't in school, I used to work a second part-time job at a local bookstore to help cover some of my expenses. It wasn't related to social work, but it gave me a chance to interact with people from different backgrounds and learn more about the community I serve. I also did some freelance writing for a nonprofit blog, which allowed me to share stories from the kids I work with. It wasn't always easy juggling everything, but I found that having different responsibilities helped me stay grounded and reminded me of the different ways I can contribute. I think the key was always knowing when to say no to something that didn't align with my goals or when I needed to focus on what truly mattered. It's not about having more—it's about being intentional with the time and energy I have.

Going through the interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my emotional well-being and financial stability are intertwined. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how far I've come in learning to take care of myself, even when life feels overwhelming. It also made me realize how much my mental health affects my ability to manage my finances and responsibilities. I used to think that being strong meant pushing through everything without asking for help, but now I see that true strength is knowing when to slow down, ask for support, and prioritize my health. When I discussed my monthly budget and how I make ends meet, it made me appreciate how much I've learned about being intentional with my money, even when it's tight. I've come to understand that financial stability isn't just about having more—it's about making the most of what I have and planning for the future, even in small ways. These reflections have helped me see that my journey isn't just about surviving—it's about thriving, even when the road is bumpy.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Lorenzo Johnson: In total, my household made just over $1,200 in the past month from my part-time job at the community center and a small stipend from my graduate program. It's not much, but it covers the basics—rent, groceries, and transportation. I also get some financial aid and occasionally do freelance writing on the side, which helps a little. It's tight, but I've learned to live within my means and prioritize what's most important. I know it's not easy, especially with the cost of living in Newark, but I'm grateful for every dollar I can get. It's not about having a lot—it's about making sure I can keep going, keep learning, and keep helping others the way I was helped when I was younger.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Lorenzo Johnson: I've been at the community center for about two years now, and it's been a really formative experience. The benefits of the job aren't always the traditional ones you might expect—there's no health insurance or paid vacation days, but what I get instead is something just as valuable: purpose. I know I'm not making a lot of money, but I feel like I'm making a real difference in the lives of the kids I work with. The center also offers some professional development opportunities, like workshops on trauma-informed care and youth engagement, which have been really helpful as I work toward my master's. The best part, though, is the sense of community I feel there. Everyone there is committed to the same mission, and that makes the long hours and tight budget feel worth it. I don't have the same benefits as someone in a more traditional job, but I think the rewards are just as real, if not more so.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Lorenzo Johnson: My relationships at work are pretty much like family. I have a great relationship with my manager, Ms. Thompson. She's been like a second mother to me, always pushing me to be better while also giving me the space I need to grow. She's seen me through a lot—through my back injury, through the times I've struggled with anxiety, and through the moments when I've felt like I wasn't enough. She never treated me like I was just an intern; she treated me like someone who had a real voice and a real purpose. As for my coworkers, we all have this unspoken understanding that we're in this together. We're not just coworkers—we're a team, and we support each other in ways that go beyond the job. Whether it's helping each other with last-minute projects or just checking in on one another when things get tough, I feel like I'm part of something bigger. That kind of connection makes the long hours and tight budget feel less heavy, because I know I'm not alone in this.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Lorenzo Johnson: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's also a fair amount of flexibility, which I really appreciate. I usually work Tuesday through Friday afternoons, and those days are pretty set in stone. But if something comes up—like a community meeting or a workshop I need to attend—I can usually adjust my hours or swap shifts with a coworker. The center understands that we're all juggling a lot, especially with school and personal responsibilities. That flexibility is something I don't take for granted. It allows me to be there for the kids when they need me most, even if it means staying late or coming in early. I think that kind of adaptability is what makes this place special—it's not just about showing up; it's about showing up when it matters, and knowing that the people around you will support you when you need to be supported in return.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Lorenzo Johnson: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is a constant balancing act, but I'm trying not to let it define me or my potential. It's not easy being in a place where every dollar has to be accounted for, but I've learned to be resourceful and intentional with what I have. I know I'm not in a position of wealth, but I also know that I'm not in a position of despair. I've seen too many people in my neighborhood struggle without any safety net, and I want to make sure I'm not one of them. I take pride in the fact that I'm working toward something bigger than just making ends meet—I'm working toward a future where I can help others in the same way my mom helped me. It's not always comfortable, and there are days when I feel like I'm just barely keeping up, but I remind myself that this is part of the journey. I believe in the power of education, the strength of community, and the importance of perseverance. As long as I keep moving forward, even if it's one step at a time, I know I'm on the right path.

Going through the interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation and work responsibilities shape my daily life and long-term goals. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the unpredictability of life and how important it is to be adaptable and resourceful. It also made me think about how much I've learned to manage my money carefully, even when it's tight, and how that discipline is part of what keeps me grounded. When I discussed my savings habits and the fact that I'm building a rainy day fund, it made me realize how much I value security—not just for myself, but for the people I want to help in the future. I used to think that having a stable income was the only way to be successful, but now I see that success is about more than just money—it's about making the most of what you have, being intentional with your time and resources, and staying committed to your purpose, even when the road is bumpy. These reflections have helped me see that my journey isn't just about surviving financially—it's about building a foundation that allows me to keep moving forward, no matter what challenges come my way.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Lorenzo Johnson: Yes, my mom worked for pay for at least a year while I was growing up—actually, she worked full-time throughout most of my childhood. She was a school administrator, which meant she had a stable job, but it also meant long hours and a lot of responsibility. I remember her coming home tired, sometimes stressed, but she always made sure I had everything I needed. She didn't just work to pay the bills; she worked to give me a better future than she had. I saw how hard she worked, how she balanced her job with being a single parent, and it taught me the value of education, responsibility, and perseverance. I don't think I would be where I am today without her sacrifices. She was the reason I always stayed focused on school, even when things got tough. I still look up to her, not just as my mom, but as a role model who showed me what it means to fight for your family and your dreams.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Lorenzo Johnson: My mom was a school administrator, which meant she was responsible for managing the day-to-day operations of the school, overseeing staff, coordinating events, and making sure everything ran smoothly for the students and faculty. Her most important activities were ensuring that the school had the resources it needed and that the teachers were supported in their work. She was also deeply involved in the community, organizing parent-teacher meetings, mentoring new staff, and advocating for better educational opportunities for kids in our neighborhood. I remember how she would come home exhausted but still find time to sit down with me and talk about my day, my grades, and my future. She didn't just work to pay the bills—she worked to make sure that kids like me had a chance to succeed. I think that's why I became so passionate about education and community work. She showed me that leadership isn't just about authority—it's about caring, about lifting others up, and about making sure that no one is left behind.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Lorenzo Johnson: My mom worked for the Newark Public School District, which is a government-run system that serves students across the city. It's a big organization, but she was part of a smaller school within it—a middle school in the heart of our neighborhood. She didn't just manage the school; she was deeply involved in every aspect of it, from curriculum planning to student support programs. She made sure that teachers had the tools they needed, that students had access to resources like tutoring and counseling, and that the school was a safe and welcoming place for everyone. I remember her telling me that her job wasn't just about administration—it was about making sure kids had a chance to dream bigger than their circumstances. She often said that education was the key to breaking cycles, and I think that's why she worked so hard. Even on her toughest days, she always found a way to give back, whether it was mentoring a new teacher or helping a student who was struggling. I think that's why I feel so connected to education and community work today—it all started with her.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Lorenzo Johnson: A few years from now, I hope I'm still in Newark, but not just for the same reasons I am now. I hope I'm not just surviving—I hope I'm thriving. I want to be a licensed social worker, working full-time at the community center or maybe even starting my own nonprofit that focuses on youth development and mental health support. I want to be the kind of person who can look back and say I made a real difference in the lives of others, especially kids who come from backgrounds like mine. I also hope I'm in a better financial position, not just for myself, but so I can invest in the community and create opportunities for others. I want to have a stable home, maybe even one I own, and I hope I'm still close to my mom and sister, supporting each other as we grow older. Most of all, I hope I'm still passionate about what I do, still learning, and still believing in the power of education, community, and resilience. I want to be someone who others can look up to, just like my mom was for me.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Lorenzo Johnson: What I value the most in my life is connection—connection to my community, to my family, and to the people I work with. I've seen how much difference it makes when you have people who believe in you, who lift you up when you're struggling, and who remind you of your worth when you forget it yourself. I value education because it's been my way out of cycles I didn't want to be part of, and I want to make sure that others have that same chance. I also value resilience—the kind of resilience that comes from growing up in a place that tests you every day but still finds a way to keep going. I value the little things too, like the sound of my mom's voice on the phone, the way my sister laughs when she's happy, or the quiet moments I have with the kids I mentor when they finally feel seen. Life hasn't been easy, but I've learned that what matters most isn't the obstacles we face—it's how we choose to face them, and who we choose to face them with.

Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the unpredictability of life and how important it is to be adaptable and resourceful. It also made me think about how much I've learned to manage my money carefully, even when it's tight, and how that discipline is part of what keeps me grounded. When I discussed my savings habits and the fact that I'm building a rainy day fund, it made me realize how much I value security—not just for myself, but for the people I want to help in the future. I used to think that having a stable income was the only way to be successful, but now I see that success is about more than just money—it's about making the most of what you have, being intentional with your time and resources, and staying committed to your purpose, even when the road is bumpy. These reflections have helped me see that my journey isn't just about surviving financially—it's about building a foundation that allows me to keep moving forward, no matter what challenges come my way.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, not just for the people who asked the questions, but for me as well. It's amazing how much you can learn about yourself when you're forced to look back at the different chapters of your life and see how each one shaped you. I never realized how much my childhood, my family, my neighborhood, and even my health struggles had influenced the person I am today. Talking about my mom, my education, my work, and my dreams reminded me of how far I've come and how much I still have to give. I've always believed in the power of education and community, but now I see how deeply those values are rooted in my experiences. This interview wasn't just about telling my story—it was about understanding it, and that understanding has given me a new sense of purpose. I know there's still a long way to go, but I'm more determined than ever to make a difference, not just for myself, but for the kids who come after me.
